section.title: Reflections Activity
section.p: To begin this activity, first an exercise about function notation.

ul.li: If f(3) means "the output when the input is 3", what does 6*f(3) mean?

solution.p: The correct answer is . The number 6 is being multiplied by the value f(3). So, whatever f(3) equals, this is just 6 times that amount.
The correct answer is . The number 6 is being multiplied by the value 7, so the result is 42.

paragraphs.title: The Opposite
paragraphs.p: The symbol "–" is commonly referred to as a “negative sign”, but it often helps to read it as “the opposite of”.

For instance, we can interpret the expression -3 as the opposite of 3, and we can interpret 13 as the opposite of -13. If a is any number, then -a is the opposite of a, regardless of whether a itself is actually positive or negative.
This is particularly useful when we don't know if a variable is positive or negative.
We refer to -x as the opposite of x, and we avoid saying "negative" x.

section.p: Check your understanding in the next exercise, where you will locate the opposite of a number.

section.p: For a function f(x), if f(-5) is a positive number, then -f(-5) will negative, and if f(2) is a negative number, then -f(2) will be positive.
The same input was used, but the outputs are opposites.
However, f(4) and f(-4) are not related, because the inputs are different. The only relationship is that 4 and -4 are on opposite sides of the y-axis.
In the next exercise, you will see these two scenarios from a graphical standpoint.

section.p: Our main goals in this activity are to explore evaluating a function at the opposite of the input, and taking the opposite of the output of a function.
In the next exercise, you will evaluate f(-x) and -f(x) in a table of values. Remember that the opposite just changes the sign on a number, whether it is an input or an output.
